Baguio Jan. 26, 1938
Dear da 0•
as you provably know my work in the orient nad largely to ao
with the establishment of the trans-Pacific service of Pan American®
that ob was completed last ay with the inauural flight of the China
Clipper from lanila to Hongkong, I remained in Shanghai only to permit
one of my associates to return to the U.S. for his furlough before he
assumed une auties. which 1 naa been periorming in connection with the
operations in China.
While my "number onell was on home leave the war
proke out ana lt was deemed necessary to witharaw all american 1light
and grouna personner owing to the stupla policies of the chinese unis-
ter of Communications who refused to recognize the commercial status of
the company and took no action to protect our American pilots - even
condoned the act of a young officer in compelling one of our pilots to
transport pomos at the point or a gun.
It was not long berore the
Chinese learned the folly of their ways and we then went to Nanking in
late October and early November, negotiated a new deal by going over the
head of the llinister direct to ladam Chiang Kai-shek and Dr. H. H. Kung.
The result was the granting of all our requirements, the elimination of
the inister who had given us so menv head aches and also the resienation
of the lanaging Director who was replaced by our nominee,
the comany is
now operating under the most favorable corporate organization which has
ever existed during my five years in China.
The war naturally presents
many problems most of which can be solved through radio communications.
Airplanes are in constant touch with terminals and are warned of an air -
raid in plenty of time to proceed to another field or loaf around until
the "all clear" signal is given - then fly on to destination.
Planes are
based at one end of the line at Chunking - far inland city which has not
been attacked, and at Hongkong which of course is inglish territory.
The
CNAC has been using a marvelous radio device which permits safe flight to
an exact point even if the pilot must fly completely "blind" for many
hours and the pilots who used to yearn for good weather are now happy if
there is a low solid overcast for once in the clouds no one can attack
them - even if they wanted to do so.
my "number onelt is now back on the
iob and the Bixoy family will soon be heading home.
All concessions in
Manila, Hongkong and llacao are in good shape and my work has been fairly
